results.notes:
: Lichens in genus Peltigera are often very beautiful. They have large foliose thalli with deep colors when moist. Sometimes they form very large patches on ground, rocks or wood, which may have more than 50 cm across. Particularly the green ones are very conspicuous. There are 15 species of this genus known in Slovenia (Ref.6). When thali are not well developed, or sterile, without apothecia, or dry their determination to species level may not be an easy task.

Peltigera horizontalis is relatively rare lichen in Slovenia. Horizontal, roundish apothecia is the dominant distinguishing trait. However, white underside, interwoven with almost black mesh of veins and distinctive fasciculate (in tight bundles of fibers, particularly toward their ends) rhizines are also important in determination. The species is a good indicator of old forests.

results.notes: Growing on the underside of a Prunus serotina stick with Xenasmatella vaga, an Arachnopeziza sp., and an unknown heterobasidiomycete. Nearby trees were Fagus grandifolia, Quercus spp., Carya spp. and Acer spp. Pinkish gelatinous fruiting body. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate with swollen epibasidia. Spores smooth and germinating by repetition. Spore measurements: (5.9) 6.1 – 7.6 (7.9) × (4.1) 4.7 – 6.5 (6.6) µm, Q = 1 – 1.5 (1.7); N = 21, Me = 6.7 × 5.4 µm; Qe = 1.3

May the spores be with you,

Dave “Sporesport”

MO#: 364073 iNat #: 22621409

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.

SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.

HABIT: Few (5 within 1-foot area) Clustered.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Full sun (100% of day)

ODOR: Pleasant Mushroom scent.

TASTE: Not tasted, but considered Edible.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: White, turban shaped, ¾ “ – 1.5” wide, ½ ” – 1.5” tall. Pure white at first, turning to a dull, shiny light-grey with age. Round to turban shape. Magnified surface appears to be shiny and have irregular, very fine ridges with a swirling effect across the entire area. There are also very shallow, irregularly shaped-and-placed depressions over the entire surface. A U-shaped “cup” forms the base of the Puffball, topped off by a circular-shaped Spore-Mass. Cup Flesh is white to begin with, turning a light, rusty brown with age.

GILLS: N/A

STIPE: N/A

SPORES: Spore-mass is circular, white to begin with, and with age, turning Olive Brown and powdery when dry. It sits atop the U-shaped “cup” of the Puffball.

Mycelia: White, sparse, running shallow in the packed substrate, ~ ¼ ”.
results.location_name: Clover Park Technical College (CP Tech), Lakewood, Pierce Co., Washington, USA

MO#: 364075 iNat #: nnnnnnnn

COMMON NAME: Poison Paxillus

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.

SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.

HABIT: ~ 12 – 15 loosely concentrated near the drip line of one Birch, next to a sidewalk.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Full Sun

ODOR: Fruity, becoming putrid with age.

TASTE: Per other references: Acidic and known to be Poisonous.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Yellowish-brown to light rusty-brown when mature. Convex to broadly Convex with a strongly in-rolled margin, becoming plano-convex to centrally depressed, and ~ 1” – 3.5” wide. Flesh is light-pinkish-brown, thick, very firm, and turning medium brown where cut or bruised. Somewhat viscid/tacky when wet, otherwise smooth with a somewhat “bumpiness”. The surface has a unique area just inside the margin…there is a ~ ½ “ wide complete ring that is similar to railroad ties on a track. The “ties” are a darker brown and are about 1-2 mm wide, each “tie” has a slightly waviness over their length…each “tie” is different from the others.

GILLS: Decurrent, running down the stem for ~ ½ “. They are crowded with an appearance of being in sets-of-3, which roughly align with cap’s “ties”; often becoming convoluted. They are yellowish to pale cinnamon or pale olive; bruising olive-brown to reddish brown. The gills separate from the cap in a layer (almost like the separable tube layers in boletes). Specimens at an advanced-age have gills which are dark-brown

STIPE: Tapered, 1.5 “ – 3 “ long, ½ “ – 1.5 “ thick, and sturdy. It is dry; smooth or finely hairy; colored like the cap or paler; bruising brownish to reddish brown. The end of the stipe is a dark-brown, about where the stipe is imbedded within the substrate. The flesh is thick and firm, yellowish, discoloring light-pink to medium-brown when cut.

SPORES: Brown to Dark-Brown.

MYCELIA: Appear to be Brown, intermixed with the roots of the grass and moss.
results.location_name: Clover Park Technical College (CP Tech), Lakewood, Pierce Co., Washington, USA

MO#: nnnnnn iNat #: nnnnnnnn

NEARBY FLORA: Black Oak…an Eastern America Hardwood

SUBSTRATE: Dense Humus Soil, covered by Large Conifer Nuggets/Chunks

HABIT: 8+ within 1-foot area in two Clusters directly under the tree, but near the drip line.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial shade to full sun

ODOR: Sweet, fresh potato-like.

TASTE: N/A, designated Poisonous.

NOTE: According to reference manuals and internet sources, this fungus grows only in the area East of the Rocky Mountains. The tree where these samples were found are an import to this area, planted for ornamental reasons.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: White with a variably sized area where a lemon-to-pale-greenish-yellow coloring shows. Ostensibly, there should be pale white patches on the cap top, but these can easily be removed by heavy rains…this did happen two days before the specimens were discovered. Size is 2”-4”, Convex, becoming flat, and somewhat fragile. No effect where cut or bruised. Somewhat viscid/tacky when wet. When dry, the cap has a definite sheen to it, and on one of the specimens, the cap started to turn a pale buff color. Margin is distinct, regular, sharp edges, but not radially lined.

GILLS: White, mostly free with a very short and thin continuation onto the Stipe. Very crowded, thin, moderately broad, and fragile. No effect where cut or bruised.

STIPE: White, bulbous, central attachment, smooth w/very fine and closely spaced vertically running striations. Stipe length is ~ 4”-5” and a width of ~ ¼ “ – ½ “, with a definite trapezoidal shape showing where it joins the cap. It is at the top of this region one can see, with a magnifying lens, very-small, short, gill-continuation. Remnants of a very thin veil are evident about 1” down from the stipe’s top. Flesh is white, fibrous, and somewhat fragile. There is a channel 2-3mm wide running centrally down the length of the stipe. No effect where cut or bruised.

SPORES: White

MYCELIA: Unknown color and concentration. They appear to run very deep in the packed substrate since removal of the specimens required digging down to the bottom of the stipe.

COMMON NAME: Coconut Smelly Milky

MO#: 364078 iNat #: 22623884

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.
SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.
HABIT: Several (about 5- 10) found loosely concentrated near all of the Birch Trees.
LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Full Sun
ODOR: Coconut smell.
TASTE: Very Acrid.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Pale Buff color, ~ 1” – 3” wide, thin and fragile; Convex with an in-rolled Margin when young, becoming shallowly Depressed, flat, usually becoming shallowly vase-shaped; dry; bald; finely roughened; pinkish buff – more so in the depressed area; sometimes featuring vague concentric zones of color or texture.

GILLS: Adnexed and extremely fragile; close, almost crowded; short-gills frequent; whitish to pale-yellow; not bruising or discoloring. Milk: White; often scanty; not changing on exposure to air.

STIPE: Insubstantial, either Equal or Clavate; dry, with irregularly shaped and dispersed striations running vertically; colored like the cap or paler. The length ranges from ~ 1” to 3.5”, with a thickness of ~ ½ “ – ¾ ”, depending on age. No color change where cut or bruised. The stipe is fragile, having a very-thin outer wall ~¼ “. All specimens were hollow inside, more than likely eaten out by fungus fly maggots.

SPORES: Cream.

MYCELIA: Unknown.
results.location_name: Clover Park Technical College (CP Tech), Lakewood, Pierce Co., Washington, USA

COMMON NAME: Peppery Milky

MO#: nnnnnn iNat #: nnnnnnnn

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.

SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.

HABIT: Several (about 10-12) found loosely concentrated near all of the Birch Trees. One cluster, in a 1” x 2” area had six closely packed specimens, with caps ranging from ~ ⅛“ – 1” across.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Full Sun.

ODOR: Pleasant Nutty smell.

TASTE: Very Peppery.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

NOTE: Normally associated with oaks and other hardwoods; growing scattered, gregariously, or sometimes in dense troops; summer; apparently widely distributed east of the Rocky Mountains. This specimen was found under Decorative Oaks of unknown species.

CAP: Pale Buff color, ~ 1” – 3.5” wide. At first convex with a central depression (Umbilicate); becoming somewhat flat, with a shallow central depression, eventually becoming vase-shaped at maturity. The margin is in-rolled and has a cottony tuft right on the edge of the margin. ; at first bald, but soon roughening, becoming torn into patches or scales; , but still soft; white at first, soon discoloring tan and brownish. The flesh is tough and firm and of the same color as the Cap top.

GILLS: A very-pale flesh color; decurrent (running down shortly after the stipe starts) and stopping irregularly; close, but equally spaced. Light-brown where cut or bruised, and emitting an almost clear milky substance when cut.

STIPE: Pale Buff color, except at the near the base it is a darker buff/brown. It has a more-or-less Equal shape, although one specimen had a slight U-shape curve. The caps are centrally attached, basically smooth, but under close inspection there appears to be fine, widespread bumps, like a rash. The length ranges from ~ 1” to 3.5”, with a thickness of ~ ½ “ – 1.5”, depending on age. No color change where cut or bruised. The outer ¼ “ of the stipe is hard, tough and firm, but the rest of the inside is almost gelatinous. All older specimens found were hollow…eaten out by fungus fly maggots.

SPORES: White

MYCELIA: unknown
results.location_name: Clover Park Technical College (CP Tech), Lakewood, Pierce Co., Washington, USA

MO#: 364110 iNat #: 22632948

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.

SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.

HABIT: Several (about 8-10) found loosely concentrated near all of the Birch Trees.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Full Sun.
ODOR: Mild, pleasant mushroom smell

TASTE: Unknown.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: ~ 2-3” across; pale Tan near margin, getting darker towards depressed center. Very fine, irregular cracking and fine, flattened fibers visible. In-rolled margin.

GILLS: Free, crowded, narrow. Very-pale tan.

STIPE: ~ 2-3”, Length is about the same as the diameter of the Cap. It is about 3/8 – ½” wide, fairly full until the bulbous base which is hollow. It is smooth, about the same color as the cap.

VEIL: White, partial, membranous, and persistent when separated from the cap. It is easily moved up and down the stipe at that point.

SPORES: Purple brown

MO#: 364211 iNat #: nnnnnnnn

NEARBY FLORA: Introduced (Nursery) Paper Birch Trees, Rhododendrons, occasional Sword Ferns, bordered by Grass on North edge. Can also be associated with Firs.

SUBSTRATE: Wood Bark mulch and occasional open soil, w/patches of Moss on top.

HABIT: Many (about 6-15) found loosely concentrated near or between several Birch Trees residing alongside the building.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Shade.

ODOR: None.

TASTE: Reported to be Acrid.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: ~2-6+” wide. It is Hemispheric and Smooth at first, becoming depressed, whereas with age it can develop a belly-button-like center; The Cap is initially Olive Brown with some green to buff bands with these zones being lost with age. Also with age the Cap becomes a dingy, dark/Blackish Brown, especially when dry. Otherwise it is very viscid/tacky when wet, which accumulates all kinds of small matter blown up by the wind. At first the Margin is in-rolled, distinct, regular, and having sharp edges. However, with age it becomes distinctly wavy. Flesh is white, thick, very firm, and turning light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

GILLS: Dull White to Buff, Decurrent, Crowded, but equally spaced. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised, and exuding a white, unchanging latex.

STIPE: White, more-or-less Equal, Central attachment. Olive-buff at top becoming Olive Brown. It is smooth w/very fine and closely spaced vertically running ridges, along with a few irregularly placed Dark Brown spots; length is ~1.5 – 6”. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

SPORES: Buff.

MYCELIA: Light Olive-brown

NOTE: There are several look-a-likes (especially as they age) with this species, including:
L, necator
L. turpis
L. atroviridis
L. aurantiosordidus
L. sordidus
So….getting a DNA test of any sample would go a long way towards confirming identities.

results.notes:
Growing within soil, around some debris. Fruiting body about 5-8 cm tall, cap about 1-1.5 cm wide. Cap initially deeper cinnamon color to rusty brown, fading to a more tan, light-brown upon maturity, the margin retaining the deeper (initial) colors; without striations on the cap, though cap margin sometimes becoming slightly lined in age. Gills with lighter shades of brown, becoming deeper brownish-yellow (rusty brown) as spores mature and collect on the gill faces. Stipe concolorous with mature cap, a bit lighter in immature specimens, delicate and pubescent (especially at the apex), longitudinally striate, slightly twisted.

Basidiospores ~ (10.5) 11.8 – 12.5 (13.0 – 13.3) x 7.0 – 7.5 (8.0) μm; Q = 1.5 – 1.8; (95% Conf: L x W = 12.0 – 12.6 × 7.0 – 7.3 μm; Q = 1.68 – 1.76); Pleurocystidia absent; Cheilocystidia ~ 17.0 – 22.0 × 6.5 – 8.0 μm (95% Conf: L x W = 18.3 – 20.7 × 6.9 – 7.6 μm), capitellum ~ 3.0 – 5.5 μm broad/wide; Pileus cuticle hymeniform/celluar; pileocystidia scare or infrequent, mostly cylindrical or lecythiform; caulocystidia non-lecythiform, mainly cylindric to filamentous, sometimes clavate.

results.notes:
On sandstone in a grassy meadow on the ridge of the Santa Lucia Range above Cayucos.

Thallus poorly developed, brown, areolate to subsquamulose (barely), rarely overlapping. Apothecia lecanorine, convex, with a thalline margin reduced but persistent, filled with algae. All parts POL-. Epihymenium reddish brown, pigment not soluble in K, POL-. Hymenium hyaline, amyloid. Paraphyses and asci coherent and difficult to separate. Paraphyses segmented, tips swollen. Asci K/I+blue, but so dark and coherent that detail of the tholus amyloidity was not observed. Hypothecium hyaline, prosoplectenchymatous. Pycnidia not seen.

Spores 8/ascus, simple to 1-septate, hyaline, ellipsoid, about 15.5×5.5µm.

This seems to be one of the Lecania brunonis group species, I need to get better references to separate L. brunonis, L. frutigena, and L. pacifica.

Common Name: Peppery Bolete

MO#: 364251 iNat #: 22743017

NEARBY FLORA: Introduced/Nursery Beech Tree, Boletus Barrowsii (Barrows Bolete).

SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.

HABIT: Few (4 within 1-foot area).

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Shade to Partial Shade

ODOR: Indistinct

TASTE: Very Peppery/Acrid.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Convex, smooth, dry, initially Yellow-Brown to Orange-Cinnamon, ~1.5” wide. Flesh is Pale Yellow, thick, very firm, and turning light-brown where cut or bruised. Somewhat viscid/tacky when wet. Margin is in-turned, distinct, regular, with slightly curved edges. The flesh is solid and light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

PORES: ~ .5 – 1cm thick, somewhat depressed, ochre/dark red in color.

STIPE: Centered on the Cap, ~ 1.5 – 2” long, and ~ ½” at the thickest point, equal to tapering slightly at the base. The exterior has very-small, light-Reddish-Brown “tufts” over yellow, with the base being Bright Yellow. Internally a Lemon Yellow color. The flesh is solid and light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

SPORES: Reportedly Dull Cinnamon.

MYCELIA: UNKNOWN

results.notes: Growing on the underside of a Prunus serotina stick with Xenasmatella vaga, Tulasnella violea and Everhartia lignatilis. Sparse, whitish subiculum present. Hairs hyaline, cylindrical, thin-walled, septate and smooth over much of their length with basal incrustation. Ectal excipulum of textura angularis. MO#: nnnnnn iNat #: nnnnnnnn

NEARBY FLORA: Conifers: Douglas Fir, Hemlock; Deciduous: Big-leaf Maple, Vine Maple, Red Huckleberry; Sword and Deer Fern.

SUBSTRATE: Dead Conifer Limb, Moss, Needle Duff.

HABIT: Cluster of 15 – 20.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Shade, partial shade.

ODOR: Slightly Mushroomy

TASTE: Ostensibly mild, faintly Radish.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Hemispheric becoming flat with age. ~ ¼ – 1” wide. Color varies depending on dampness (i.e., hygrophanous) with a majority of the specimens in this sample having a pale brown color on the upper half and a darker, hazel-brown on the remainder. Margin is striate, with ivory-or-dingy-cream-like color on the edges from the veil. Flesh is thin, fragile, and buff colored throughout when sliced.

GILLS: Pale Buff-Brown, becoming Cinnamon-Brown with age. They are primaily , adnate with some being sub-decurrent, crowded, but equally spaced. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

STIPE: ~ ½ – 1.5” tall, thick, equal, rounded to flattened, hollow, smooth, with a dingy medium-brown color. Little is left of the veil, with the most being found on the Cap Margin. At the very end there is a collection of what appear to be Dense Mycelia.

SPORES: Pale Orange-brown.

MYCELIA: White, very dense, quite a bit of it is above the top layer of the dead wood and appears to be an extension of the Stipe. Appears to run shallow in the piece of wood, ~ ¼”.

results.notes:
On shale cobble in a semi-arid annual grassland habitat.

Thallus consists of chocolate brown bullate areoles tightly arranged, nearly always with a depression in the center of the areoles that collects dust or a crusty pruina. Cortex C-. All parts POL-. Apothecia originating immersed, 1(3) per areole, without an elevated parathecial crown, with thalline margin, with red-brown disk, emerging to completely envelop the areole and appear sessile with a nearly black disk and rims lacking algae. Algae across the base of the apothecia is thick but becomes sparse. Epihymenium reddish. Hymenium hyaline. Exciple with a hyaline space between cortex and algae, always continuing over the algae into the hymenium. Paraphyses simple, filiform, with oil drops, segmented, slightly enlarged near tip to <2µm. Asci with many tiny spores. Pycnida not observed, but needs further inspection.

Spores many per ascus, small, 4-6×2µm.

This is an interesting Acarospora that shows development of pseudolecanorine-like apothecia. It is similar in micro features to the newly described Acarospora erratica, but that one occurs on calcareous rock. Knudsen didn’t recognize this one from photo. It will be sent to him in Prague for sequencing.

results.notes: Fruiting solitarily, under pine, hickory, oak and some sweetgum trees. Cap mostly purple, darker on the disc, some yellowish-olivaceous tones present. Stipe somewhat hollow. Gills attached, not forked, white though becoming more yellowish upon handling and drying; Deposit white – Taste mild, becoming faintly acrid within about 10 seconds, cuticle peeling relatively easy (>1/2), flesh grayish beneath cuticle. Spores subglobose to ellipsoid, ~ 7-9 × 5-6.5 μm, with scattered connections forming broken to partial reticula. Pleuro-and cheilocystidia abundant, fusiform to kind of mucronate, ~61-74 × 9-12 μm. Pileipellis a cutis with elements that are septate ~ 2.8-6 μm thick; pileocystidia long and slender with fusiform to subcapitate, or constricted tips; ochraceous-refractive in KOH.
